record.question: Did you have any conflict with Dr. Eleanor Hawthorne before last night?
record.feedback: Not that I can recall. Why do you ask?

record.question: What were you doing between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: I was at home, going over some notes for a presentation due the next day.

record.question: Were you in the Old Manor Library between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: No, I was at home preparing dinner and couldn't have been in the library.

record.question: What were you doing between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: I was at home, trying to make sense of everything that happened today and avoid thinking about Dr. Reed's death.

record.question: Were you in the Old Manor Library between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: No, I was already at home by 6:00 PM.

record.question: Were you alone in the Old Manor Library between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: No, I was there with some friends for a book club meeting. We finished around 8pm and said our goodbyes.

record.question: Did you have any personal grudge against Dr. Jonathan Reed?
record.feedback: Not really; we've had our disagreements, but nothing personal. He's always been a bit too competitive for my liking.

record.question: Did you notice anything unusual or suspicious about the Old Manor Library that evening?
record.feedback: Not really, everything seemed normal until I heard about Dr. Reed's death on the news.

record.question: Have you ever had any disputes with Dr. Jonathan Reed?
record.feedback: Oh, we had our disagreements, but mostly about the authenticity of certain items. He was very thorough and sometimes too critical.

record.question: Did you have any reason to be upset with Dr. Jonathan Reed that evening?
record.feedback: Not really, why do you ask? He's been quite helpful with my research project. Why are you asking about him?

record.question: Do you have any alibi for the time of Dr. Jonathan Reed's death?
record.feedback: I was at the library working on some research until it closed. I can ask Clara Whitmore for a statement if needed.

record.question: Did you see anyone unusual in the Old Manor Library that evening?
record.feedback: I didn't see anyone unusual; it was mostly quiet, as it usually is after hours.

record.question: Did you have any access to the antique brass candlestick that evening?
record.feedback: No, I wasn't near any candlesticks that night. I was just at home, going over some notes and feeling really stressed about everything.

record.question: Did you touch or move the antique brass candlestick that evening?
record.feedback: I touched it briefly when we were discussing a scene from the book we were reading, but I didn't move it. Why? Is something wrong with it?

record.question: Did you have any opportunity to leave your home undetected between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: I was hosting a dinner party at my place, but unfortunately, all my guests left by 8:30 PM.

record.question: Did you have any reason to want Dr. Jonathan Reed dead?
record.feedback: The grant he received made me feel jealous, but that doesn't mean I wanted him dead.

record.question: Did you notice anything suspicious about the antique brass candlestick before or after the incident?
record.feedback: I didn't notice anything suspicious about the candlestick until after the incident. It was just an old decoration on the table.

record.question: Did you have any enemies or people who might want to harm you that evening?
record.feedback: Not that I know of, but lately, things have been so tense and unpredictable. Who knows what someone might do?

record.question: Who did you discuss the book with in the library that evening?
record.feedback: We had a mix of people there—some from the history department, a few literature majors, and even someone from the art history club. We talked about various interpretations of the book's setting.

record.question: Did you have any reason to be angry at Dr. Jonathan Reed that evening?
record.feedback: Our interactions were sometimes tense due to academic disagreements, but anger to the point of wanting someone dead is extreme.

record.question: Did you have any opportunity to leave the library and return undetected between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: I left the library at 5:30 PM and wouldn't have had time to return before 7pm.

record.question: Did you have any reason to be angry at Dr. Jonathan Reed that evening?
record.feedback: Just the usual academic tensions, but I don't think that would lead someone to commit murder.

record.question: Did you have any physical access to the antique brass candlestick that evening?
record.feedback: I don't think so, I was just at home, you know, dealing with some paperwork and trying to calm down.

record.question: Did you have any opportunity to leave the library and return undetected between 7pm and 9pm last evening?
record.feedback: Sure, I could have easily gone to the restroom or grabbed a snack from the café across the street. Libraries can get pretty crowded, so it wouldn't be hard to slip out and back in.

record.question: Did you have any reason to be physically close to Dr. Jonathan Reed that evening?
record.feedback: We had a scheduled meeting at the library, but it was just a professional discussion.

record.question: What were you doing with the antique marble bust between 7pm and 9pm last night?
record.feedback: I was assisting Dr. Eleanor Blackwood in setting up her presentation materials and later checking on the security of all artifacts, including the antique marble bust.
